sentences: Randolph Charles Bachman  (; born September 27, 1943) is a Canadian guitarist, singer, and songwriter.
section: N/A

sentences: He was a founding member of the bands The Guess Who and Bachman–Turner Overdrive.
section: N/A

sentences: Bachman recorded as a solo artist and was part of a number of short-lived bands such as Brave Belt, Union and Ironhorse.
section: N/A

sentences: He was a national radio personality on CBC Radio, hosting the weekly music show, Vinyl Tap.
section: N/A

sentences: Bachman was inducted into the Musicians Hall of Fame and Museum in 2016.
section: N/A
== Early life and education ==

sentences: Early life and education
section: == Early life and education ==
== Early life and education ==

sentences: Born in Winnipeg, Manitoba, to Karl (Charlie) Bachman and Anne (Nancy) Dobrinsky, Bachman is of half-German and half-Ukrainian descent.
section: == Early life and education ==

sentences: At age three, he won a singing contest on CKY's King of the Saddle program and age five he had started studying the violin in the Royal Toronto Conservatory system.
section: == Early life and education ==

sentences: He studied violin until the age of 12 when he grew dissatisfied with the structured lessons.
section: == Early life and education ==

sentences: He found that while he couldn't read music, he could play anything if he heard it once; he referred to it as his phonographic memory.
section: == Early life and education ==

sentences: At age 15, Bachman saw Elvis Presley play on Tommy Dorsey's television show and the sight of the guitar around Presley's neck inspired him.
section: == Early life and education ==

sentences: He learned three chords from his cousin, then started practising on a modified Hawaiian dobro.
section: == Early life and education ==

sentences: At age 16, Bachman met Lenny Breau and during the next two years Breau taught Bachman finger picking.
section: == Early life and education ==

sentences: Breau also introduced him to Chet Atkins' music.
section: == Early life and education ==

sentences: In 1959, Bachman bought a ticket to see Les Paul in concert at a Winnipeg supper club but could not get in as he was too young.
section: == Early life and education ==

sentences: He instead helped Paul set up before the show and also helped him reload everything into the car after the show.
section: == Early life and education ==

sentences: Still a budding guitarist at this point, Bachman asked Paul if he could teach him a guitar lick; Paul ended up teaching his version of "How High the Moon".
section: == Early life and education ==

sentences: He was initially a good student at school until he took up the guitar, when he focused on that instrument to the exclusion of his education.
section: == Early life and education ==

sentences: He passed Grade 9 at Edmund Partridge Junior High School, but repeated both the 10th and 11th grades, initially at West Kildonan Collegiate.
section: == Early life and education ==

sentences: In his second year of Grade 11, he was placed in a class of students who mostly either "flunked or dropped out and came back", and was asked to be class president by the teacher, who thought he had "discipline and determination" because he had been playing violin since the age of five.
section: == Early life and education ==

sentences: He was expelled from West Kildonan in the middle of that year because of his "lack of studiousness", and finished his schooling at Garden City Collegiate.
section: == Early life and education ==

sentences: He went on to study business administration at what is now Red River College, but did not graduate.
section: == Early life and education ==

== Professional musical career == | === The Guess Who ===

sentences: The Guess
section: == Professional musical career == | === The Guess Who ===

sentences: Who ===
section: == Professional musical career == | === The Guess Who ===

sentences: In 1960, Bachman and Chad Allan co-founded Al and The Silvertones in Winnipeg.
section: == Professional musical career == | === The Guess Who ===

sentences: By 1962, the band changed their name to Chad Allan and the Expressions and later to The Guess Who.
section: == Professional musical career == | === The Guess Who ===

sentences: In 1965, the Guess Who had a #1 hit in Canada with their cover of Johnny Kidd's "Shakin' All Over", which also charted in the US at #22.
section: == Professional musical career == | === The Guess Who ===

sentences: In 1966, Chad Allan left the band and Burton Cummings became the primary vocalist.
section: == Professional musical career == | === The Guess Who ===

sentences: Between 1966 and 1968, The Guess Who laboured mostly in their home country, releasing a few singles that managed to crack the Top 40 in Canada.
section: == Professional musical career == | === The Guess Who ===

sentences: In early 1969, the group finally broke through internationally with the hit song "These Eyes", co-written by Bachman and Cummings.
section: == Professional musical career == | === The Guess Who ===

sentences: The Guess Who released three successful albums over the next two years: Wheatfield Soul (1969), Canned Wheat (1969), and American Woman (1970), which brought them mainstream attention.
section: == Professional musical career == | === The Guess Who ===

sentences: Bachman wrote or cowrote (primarily with Cummings) most of the group's songs during this period.
section: == Professional musical career == | === The Guess Who ===

sentences: In early 1970, the single "American Woman" hit #1 on the US Hot 100 charts, a first for a band from Canada.
section: == Professional musical career == | === The Guess Who ===

sentences: A group composition, the song critiques the "ghetto scenes" and "war machines" of the US, reflecting the Guess Who's experiences of extensive touring in large American cities.
section: == Professional musical career == | === The Guess Who ===

sentences: With the Vietnam War at its peak, many American men went to Canada to escape US Military service.
section: == Professional musical career == | === The Guess Who ===

sentences: Bachman left the band at the height of its popularity, shortly after the release of American Woman.
section: == Professional musical career == | === The Guess Who ===

sentences: He has been quoted as leaving due to the other band members' lifestyle choices conflicting with his beliefs upon converting to The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, in addition to wanting to spend more time with his family members.
section: == Professional musical career == | === The Guess Who ===

sentences: He was also suffering health problems related to his gall bladder and needed to be under a doctor's care, something that was difficult to do while on the road.
section: == Professional musical career == | === The Guess Who ===
== Professional musical career == | === Brave Belt and Bachman–Turner Overdrive ===

sentences: Brave Belt and Bachman–Turner Overdrive
section: == Professional musical career == | === Brave Belt and Bachman–Turner Overdrive ===
== Professional musical career == | === Brave Belt and Bachman–Turner Overdrive ===

sentences: Before his departure from The Guess Who in May 1970, Bachman recorded an instrumental solo album for RCA Records, Axe, over three days in March 1970.
section: == Professional musical career == | === Brave Belt and Bachman–Turner Overdrive ===

sentences: The following year, he formed the country rock band Brave Belt with Chad Allan.
section: == Professional musical career == | === Brave Belt and Bachman–Turner Overdrive ===

sentences: Brave Belt released its first self-titled LP in 1971.
section: == Professional musical career == | === Brave Belt and Bachman–Turner Overdrive ===

sentences: Robbie Bachman was the drummer for Brave Belt, at barely 18 years-old.
section: == Professional musical career == | === Brave Belt and Bachman–Turner Overdrive ===

sentences: Fred Turner subsequently joined Brave Belt on bass and vocals, resulting in the band evolving into a heavier sound, which led to the departure of Chad Allan.
section: == Professional musical career == | === Brave Belt and Bachman–Turner Overdrive ===

sentences: Left with a three-member line-up, Brave Belt added Tim Bachman as a second guitarist.
section: == Professional musical career == | === Brave Belt and Bachman–Turner Overdrive ===

sentences: With this lineup, the members signed a record deal with Mercury Records and renamed the band Bachman-Turner Overdrive.
section: == Professional musical career == | === Brave Belt and Bachman–Turner Overdrive ===

sentences: Often referred to as "B.T.O." for short, they released their first self-titled album, Bachman–Turner Overdrive in May 1973.
section: == Professional musical career == | === Brave Belt and Bachman–Turner Overdrive ===

sentences: In December 1973, the band released their second album, Bachman–Turner Overdrive II.
section: == Professional musical career == | === Brave Belt and Bachman–Turner Overdrive ===

sentences: This album brought the band a greater commercial success than their debut, with hits such as "Takin' Care of Business" and "Let It Ride", which charted at #12 and #23 in the US, respectively.
section: == Professional musical career == | === Brave Belt and Bachman–Turner Overdrive ===

sentences: In 1974, they released their third album titled, Not Fragile.
section: == Professional musical career == | === Brave Belt and Bachman–Turner Overdrive ===

sentences: The release hit #1 on the album charts in both Canada and the United States.
section: == Professional musical career == | === Brave Belt and Bachman–Turner Overdrive ===

sentences: The album contained the hits, "Roll On Down the Highway" and "You Ain't Seen Nothin'
section: == Professional musical career == | === Brave Belt and Bachman–Turner Overdrive ===

sentences: Yet", which charted at #14 and #1, respectively.
section: == Professional musical career == | === Brave Belt and Bachman–Turner Overdrive ===

sentences: With the latter, Randy had the rare accomplishment of recording an American chart-topper for two different Canadian bands; the other being "American Woman" while he was in The Guess Who.
section: == Professional musical career == | === Brave Belt and Bachman–Turner Overdrive ===

sentences: The band remained on the charts through the mid-1970s with their next two albums, Four Wheel Drive and Head On.
section: == Professional musical career == | === Brave Belt and Bachman–Turner Overdrive ===

sentences: With these albums, they successfully had additional hit songs with "Hey You", "Take It Like a Man", and the jazz-oriented "Lookin' Out For No. 1".
section: == Professional musical career == | === Brave Belt and Bachman–Turner Overdrive ===

sentences: In late-1976, during the recording of their sixth studio album Freeways, some disagreements surfaced within the band.
section: == Professional musical career == | === Brave Belt and Bachman–Turner Overdrive ===

sentences: Bachman wrote all but one song and sang on every song but two, while some of the other band members felt that they didn't have enough good material to record and wanted to delay the release.
section: == Professional musical career == | === Brave Belt and Bachman–Turner Overdrive ===

sentences: Upon its release, the album charted at #70 in the US, but had no hit singles.
section: == Professional musical career == | === Brave Belt and Bachman–Turner Overdrive ===

sentences: Randy Bachman officially quit the band in mid-March 1977.
section: == Professional musical career == | === Brave Belt and Bachman–Turner Overdrive ===

sentences: The rest of the band would continue to record and tour until the end of the decade, after Randy agreed to sell the rights to the "BTO" name to the remaining band members.
section: == Professional musical career == | === Brave Belt and Bachman–Turner Overdrive ===
== Professional musical career == | === 1979–1981 ===
== Professional musical career == | === 1979–1981 ===

sentences: After his departure from Bachman-Turner Overdrive, Bachman recorded a second solo album titled, Survivor.
section: == Professional musical career == | === 1979–1981 ===

sentences: This release failed to chart in the US.
section: == Professional musical career == | === 1979–1981 ===

sentences: Following the solo album, he formed a new rock band with bassist/singer Tom Sparks, called Ironhorse.
section: == Professional musical career == | === 1979–1981 ===

sentences: Ironhorse released their debut self-titled album in 1979.
section: == Professional musical career == | === 1979–1981 ===

sentences: It contained the single "Sweet Lui-Louise", which charted at #36 in the US and #26 in Canada, and performed well in other parts of Europe including Italy.
section: == Professional musical career == | === 1979–1981 ===

sentences: After the tour for this album, Tom Sparks left the band and was replaced by Frank Ludwig.
section: == Professional musical career == | === 1979–1981 ===

sentences: The band released a second album in 1980 titled, Everything Is Grey.
section: == Professional musical career == | === 1979–1981 ===

sentences: The release contained pop rock influences with greater use of keyboards than the first album.
section: == Professional musical career == | === 1979–1981 ===

sentences: After BTO broke up in early-1980, Fred Turner and Randy formed a new band called Union, and released only one album titled, On Strike in 1981.
section: == Professional musical career == | === 1979–1981 ===

sentences: Later in the documentary From Rags to Riches and Back, Randy recalled building up a net worth of close to $10 million by 1977, only to go broke within four years.
section: == Professional musical career == | === 1979–1981 ===

sentences: He credits these events to his divorce from his first wife Lorayne Stevenson and the court battles over custody of their children, as well as heavy investment in musical projects that did not become fruitful.
section: == Professional musical career == | === 1979–1981 ===

sentences: === 1980s–1990s and reunions ===
section: == Professional musical career == | === 1980s–1990s and reunions ===

sentences: Bachman rejoined The Guess Who in 1983 with Burton Cummings and other members of the American Woman era, for a publicized reunion.
section: == Professional musical career == | === 1980s–1990s and reunions ===

sentences: The band toured Canada and released a video of live performances.
section: == Professional musical career == | === 1980s–1990s and reunions ===

sentences: After The Guess Who reunion ended, Bachman rejoined Bachman-Turner Overdrive with Fred Turner, Tim Bachman, and Garry Peterson of The Guess Who taking over on drums.
section: == Professional musical career == | === 1980s–1990s and reunions ===

sentences: The reformed band released the self-titled Bachman-Turner Overdrive in 1984, as well as a live album in 1986, after which they opened for Van Halen during the 5150 tour in 1986.
section: == Professional musical career == | === 1980s–1990s and reunions ===

sentences: By 1987, Randy left the band.
section: == Professional musical career == | === 1980s–1990s and reunions ===

sentences: By 1988, Bachman-Turner Overdrive had reformed again, this time with the popular 1974–77 lineup.
section: == Professional musical career == | === 1980s–1990s and reunions ===

sentences: The band toured together until 1991, when Randy again departed.
section: == Professional musical career == | === 1980s–1990s and reunions ===

sentences: Randy returned to The Guess Who for a reunion performance in August 1999, in Winnipeg at the end of the XIII Pan Am Games.
section: == Professional musical career == | === 1980s–1990s and reunions ===
== Professional musical career == | === 2000s ===
== Professional musical career == | === 2000s ===

sentences: Bachman continued as a member of The Guess Who, and played with them on several tours.
section: == Professional musical career == | === 2000s ===

sentences: In 2000, he made a guest appearance on The Simpsons in an episode as himself, in a fictionalized reunion with his former Bachman–Turner Overdrive band-mates, C.F. Turner and Robin Bachman.
section: == Professional musical career == | === 2000s ===

sentences: Series creator Matt Groening, whose father is originally from Winnipeg, is a self-professed fan of the band.
section: == Professional musical career == | === 2000s ===

sentences: During their performance in the episode, Homer Simpson humorously yells "get to the working overtime part" while they perform "Takin' Care of Business".
section: == Professional musical career == | === 2000s ===

sentences: In 2001, Bachman received an honourary Doctorate of Music from Brandon University in Brandon, Manitoba, along with the other members of The Guess Who.
section: == Professional musical career == | === 2000s ===

sentences: That year he won three SOCAN Classic Awards.
section: == Professional musical career == | === 2000s ===

sentences: In 2005, Bachman was awarded the Order of Manitoba, the highest award in the Province of Manitoba.
section: == Professional musical career == | === 2000s ===

sentences: He was inducted into Canada's Walk of Fame for the first time, for his time with The Guess Who in 2001.
section: == Professional musical career == | === 2000s ===

sentences: In 2002, The Guess Who were recipients of The Governor General's Performing Arts Award, Canada's foremost distinction for excellence in the performing arts.
section: == Professional musical career == | === 2000s ===

sentences: By July 2003, Bachman left The Guess Who with singer Burton Cummings, only to form a new project called, Bachman Cummings.
section: == Professional musical career == | === 2000s ===

sentences: In 2004, Bachman helped Kalan Porter on his debut album, 219 Days.
section: == Professional musical career == | === 2000s ===

sentences: He reportedly suggested that Kalan do a drone on the violin during "In Spite of It All".
section: == Professional musical career == | === 2000s ===

sentences: He was also featured performing a guitar solo near the end of the song, "And We Drive".
section: == Professional musical career == | === 2000s ===

sentences: During this period, Bachman has also released an album of original melodic-jazz songs titled, Jazz Thing.
section: == Professional musical career == | === 2000s ===

sentences: By the summer of 2005, Bachman began hosting the coast-to-coast radio show Vinyl Tap on CBC Radio One.
section: == Professional musical career == | === 2000s ===

sentences: For the show, he played audio recordings, primarily Classic rock music, while reminiscing about personal encounters with famous artists and musicians from his 50-year career in rock music.
section: == Professional musical career == | === 2000s ===

sentences: The show ran for 16 seasons with its final episode on Canada Day, July 1, 2021, after it was cancelled by CBC, though Bachman said he planned to take the program to another broadcaster or turn it into a podcast.
section: == Professional musical career == | === 2000s ===

sentences: On July 2, 2005, Bachman performed at the Canadian leg of the global Live 8 mega-concert organized by Bob Geldof.
section: == Professional musical career == | === 2000s ===

sentences: In 2008, he was made an Officer of the Order of Canada.
section: == Professional musical career == | === 2000s ===

sentences: Bachman continued his career touring with the Randy Bachman Band, as well as the Bachman-Cummings Band.
section: == Professional musical career == | === 2000s ===

sentences: During this time he featured in a theater-styled show called "Every Song Tells A Story", where he performed live and unplugged with his band, often telling the stories behind writing his most famous from the 1960s and 1970s.
section: == Professional musical career == | === 2000s ===

sentences: Bachman and Burton Cummings performed throughout Canada as Bachman & Cummings in the summer of 2006, while on tour with The Carpet Frogs.
section: == Professional musical career == | === 2000s ===

sentences: Bachman and Fred Turner completed a new Bachman & Turner album that was released in September 2010.
section: == Professional musical career == | === 2000s ===

sentences: The album's single titled "Rollin' Along", was released in June 2010 on iTunes.
section: == Professional musical career == | === 2000s ===

sentences: The pair launched a two-year world tour (2010–11) under their Bachman & Turner moniker, beginning at the Sweden Rock Festival in June 2010.
section: == Professional musical career == | === 2000s ===

sentences: Other confirmed dates included the High Voltage Festival in London, UK, in July 2010 and the Manitoba Homecoming Event in Winnipeg, Manitoba.
section: == Professional musical career == | === 2000s ===

sentences: The pair released the next single, "Rock n' Roll Is the Only Way Out" on their official website.
section: == Professional musical career == | === 2000s ===

== Professional musical career == | === The 2010s ===

sentences: Bachman was inducted into Canada's Walk of Fame for the second time, albeit as a solo artist in 2012.
section: == Professional musical career == | === The 2010s ===

sentences: In June 2015, he also received SOCAN's Lifetime Achievement Award.
section: == Professional musical career == | === The 2010s ===

sentences: In 2014, he released a home video package of his "Every Song Tells A Story" performances, which includes an occasional accompanying symphonic orchestra.
section: == Professional musical career == | === The 2010s ===

sentences: In 2015, he released an album titled Heavy Blues from his newly-formed self-titled band, Bachman.
section: == Professional musical career == | === The 2010s ===

sentences: The album was influenced by classic 1960s blues rock and features musical contributions from other musicians including: Neil Young, Joe Bonamassa, Peter Frampton, Robert Randolph, and Jeff Healey.
section: == Professional musical career == | === The 2010s ===

sentences: Later in March 2018, Randy Bachman released a tribute to George Harrison containing cover version of the latter's hits.
section: == Professional musical career == | === The 2010s ===

sentences: The album featured one original song titled "Between Two Mountains", and also featured Walter Trout on  the album's version of "While My Guitar Gently Weeps".
section: == Professional musical career == | === The 2010s ===

sentences: Randy and Fred Turner continued to tour as Bachman & Turner through 2018, when Fred amicably retired.

== Guitar style ==

sentences: Guitar style ==
section: == Guitar style ==

sentences: Bachman has stated that his guitar sound was influenced by his early violin studies, saying "when I wanted to play a rock solo, I played like it was violin...
section: == Guitar style ==

sentences: Violin is mostly slow, melodic stuff.
section: == Guitar style ==

sentences: So my guitar solos tend to be smooth, slow lines.
section: == Guitar style ==

sentences: "He has mentioned in interviews that his guitar influences include Lenny Breau, Leslie West, Wes Montgomery, George Peterson, and Hank Marvin.
section: == Guitar style ==
== Personal life ==

sentences: Personal life ==
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Bachman's first marriage was to Lorayne Stevenson (1966 to 1977).
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: With Stevenson, Bachman had six children.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: His son, Tal Bachman, is a recording artist best known for his 1999 top-20 hit song
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: "She's So High".
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: His daughter Lorelei Bachman is also a writer/musician.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: He then married Denise McCann (from 1982 to 2011), and they had one child.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: They resided on Salt Spring Island, British Columbia, Canada.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Bachman and McCann separated in 2011.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: During his early Guess Who years, his Mormon religious beliefs conflicted with the sex, drugs and rock 'n' roll lifestyle of the other band members.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Bachman had gastric bypass surgery to reduce his weight.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Bachman originally lost 60 pounds from a 380 lb frame using diet and exercise after he and his daughter Kezia Bachman became acutely aware of the threat his obesity posed to his health during a performance at Winnipeg Stadium for the 1999 Pan American Games.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Listening to her father perform No Time, Kezia realized that Randy's obesity threatened his life and remaining time on earth.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Bachman himself realized that his weight-induced back and knee pain would make touring impossible.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: But during an extended ground time following the September 11, 2001 attacks, Bachman began overeating again.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: At his next physical after the tour, his doctor told him he was morbidly obese.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: He asked, “Doesn’t morbid mean death?”
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: The doctor told him of the risks he faced as a result of his obesity.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Then Bachman remembered that the daughter of his friend Brian Wilson of The Beach Boys had successfully lost weight using bariatric surgery, and sought out her surgeon to help him.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Following surgery, he lost 155 pounds by 2006, reaching his 225 lb target weight.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Bachman also had a successful operation on his shoulder in November 2007 to repair a torn rotator cuff, which he has blamed on his decades-long use of heavy, vintage guitars.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Randy Bachman has 26 grandchildren and 4 great-grandchildren.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Bachman is a member of the Canadian charity Artists Against Racism.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Despite German-Canadian custom, Bachman says his surname is pronounced  (with a short 'a' sound as in "back"), and he uses this pronunciation when referring to himself.
section: == Personal life == | === Name pronunciation ===

sentences: The more common pronunciation of "bock-mən", especially on American radio, became so widespread however, that he did not bother correcting people after BTO became popular.
